001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003/**
004 * A relatively simple {@link IPointHash} that multiplies each of the x, y, etc. components and the state by a different
005 * constant for each (a "harmonious number" related to the golden ratio), sums them, and keeps only the upper bits.
006 * This benefits from dot-product optimizations performed by recent JVMs (since at least Java 8). It finishes each hash
007 * with an XLCG step to improve the upper bits, then it right-shifts the whole long so it fits in the desired output
008 * range (such as 8 bits for {@link #hash256(int, int, int)}), casts it to int and returns that.
009 * <br>
010 * This hash is slightly faster for some noise applications than {@link IntPointHash}, and has comparable quality, but
011 * does require a lot of math on long values, and that can be quite slow on GWT. This should probably be used primarily
012 * on desktop targets, and/or maybe mobile.
013 */
014public final class GoldPointHash extends IPointHash.IntImpl {
015
016    @Override
017    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int state) {
018        return hashAll(x, y, state);
019    }
020
021    @Override
022    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int state) {
023        return hashAll(x, y, z, state);
024    }
025
026    @Override
027    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int state) {
028        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, state);
029    }
030
031    @Override
032    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int state) {
033        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, state);
034    }
035
036    @Override
037    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int state) {
038        return hashAll(x, y, z, w, u, v, state);
039    }
040
041    /**
042     * A 32-bit-result point hash that uses multiplication with long constants.
043     * @param x x position, as an int
044     * @param y y position, as an int
045     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
046     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
047     */
048    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int s) {
049        return (int)((0xD1B54A32D192ED03L * x + 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L * y + -0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 32);
050    }
051    /**
052     * A 32-bit-result point hash that uses multiplication with long constants.
053     * @param x x position, as an int
054     * @param y y position, as an int
055     * @param z z position, as an int
056     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
057     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
058     */
059    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
060        return (int)((0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L * x + 0xBBE0563303A4615FL * y + -0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L * z + 0x89E182857D9ED689L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 32);
061    }
062
063    /**
064     * A 32-bit-result point hash that uses multiplication with long constants.
065     * @param x x position, as an int
066     * @param y y position, as an int
067     * @param z z position, as an int
068     * @param w w position, as an int
069     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
070     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
071     */
072    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
073        return (int)((0xE19B01AA9D42C633L * x + 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L * y + -0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL * z +
074                0x9A69443F36F710E7L * w + -0x881403B9339BD42DL * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 32);
075    }
076
077    /**
078     * A 32-bit-result point hash that uses multiplication with long constants.
079     * @param x x position, as an int
080     * @param y y position, as an int
081     * @param z z position, as an int
082     * @param w w position, as an int
083     * @param u u position, as an int
084     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
085     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u point with the given state s
086     */
087    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int s) {
088        return (int)((0xE60E2B722B53AEEBL * x + 0xCEBD76D9EDB6A8EFL * y + -0xB9C9AA3A51D00B65L * z +
089                0xA6F5777F6F88983FL * w + -0x9609C71EB7D03F7BL * u + 0x86D516E50B04AB1BL * s ^
090                0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 32);
091    }
092
093    /**
094     * A 32-bit-result point hash that uses multiplication with long constants.
095     * @param x x position, as an int
096     * @param y y position, as an int
097     * @param z z position, as an int
098     * @param w w position, as an int
099     * @param u u position, as an int
100     * @param v v position, as an int
101     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
102     * @return 32-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
103     */
104    public static int hashAll(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
105        return (int)((0xE95E1DD17D35800DL * x + 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL * y + -0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L * z +
106                0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL * w + -0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L * u + 0x92E852C80D153DB3L * v +
107                -0x85EB75C3024385C3L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 32);
108    }
109
110    /**
111     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
112     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
113     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
114     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
115     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
116     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
117     * @param x x position, as an int
118     * @param y y position, as an int
119     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
120     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
121     */
122    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int s) {
123        return (int)((0xD1B54A32D192ED03L * x + 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L * y + -0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 56);
124    }
125    /**
126     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
127     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
128     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
129     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
130     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
131     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
132     * @param x x position, as an int
133     * @param y y position, as an int
134     * @param z z position, as an int
135     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
136     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
137     */
138    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
139        return (int)((0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L * x + 0xBBE0563303A4615FL * y + -0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L * z + 0x89E182857D9ED689L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 56);
140    }
141
142    /**
143     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
144     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
145     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
146     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
147     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
148     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
149     * @param x x position, as an int
150     * @param y y position, as an int
151     * @param z z position, as an int
152     * @param w w position, as an int
153     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
154     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
155     */
156    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
157        return (int)((0xE19B01AA9D42C633L * x + 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L * y + -0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL * z +
158                0x9A69443F36F710E7L * w + -0x881403B9339BD42DL * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 56);
159    }
160
161    /**
162     * A 8-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
163     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
164     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
165     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
166     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
167     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
168     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
169     * @param x x position, as an int
170     * @param y y position, as an int
171     * @param z z position, as an int
172     * @param w w position, as an int
173     * @param u u position, as an int
174     * @param v v position, as an int
175     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
176     * @return 8-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
177     */
178    public static int hash256(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
179        return (int)((0xE95E1DD17D35800DL * x + 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL * y + -0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L * z +
180                0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL * w + -0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L * u + 0x92E852C80D153DB3L * v -
181                0x85EB75C3024385C3L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 56);
182    }
183
184    /**
185     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
186     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
187     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
188     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
189     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
190     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
191     * @param x x position, as an int
192     * @param y y position, as an int
193     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
194     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
195     */
196    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int s) {
197        return (int)((0xD1B54A32D192ED03L * x + 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L * y + -0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 58);
198    }
199    /**
200     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
201     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
202     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
203     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
204     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
205     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
206     * @param x x position, as an int
207     * @param y y position, as an int
208     * @param z z position, as an int
209     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
210     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
211     */
212    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
213        return (int)((0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L * x + 0xBBE0563303A4615FL * y + -0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L * z + 0x89E182857D9ED689L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 58);
214    }
215
216    /**
217     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
218     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
219     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
220     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
221     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
222     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
223     * @param x x position, as an int
224     * @param y y position, as an int
225     * @param z z position, as an int
226     * @param w w position, as an int
227     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
228     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
229     */
230    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
231        return (int)((0xE19B01AA9D42C633L * x + 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L * y + -0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL * z +
232                0x9A69443F36F710E7L * w + -0x881403B9339BD42DL * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 58);
233    }
234
235    /**
236     * A 6-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
237     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
238     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
239     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
240     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
241     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
242     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
243     * @param x x position, as an int
244     * @param y y position, as an int
245     * @param z z position, as an int
246     * @param w w position, as an int
247     * @param u u position, as an int
248     * @param v v position, as an int
249     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
250     * @return 6-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
251     */
252    public static int hash64(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
253        return (int)((0xE95E1DD17D35800DL * x + 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL * y + -0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L * z +
254                0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL * w + -0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L * u + 0x92E852C80D153DB3L * v -
255                0x85EB75C3024385C3L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 58);
256    }
257    /**
258     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x and y into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
259     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
260     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
261     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
262     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
263     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
264     * @param x x position, as an int
265     * @param y y position, as an int
266     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
267     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y point with the given state s
268     */
269    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int s) {
270        return (int)((0xD1B54A32D192ED03L * x + 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L * y + -0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 59);
271    }
272    /**
273     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, and z into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
274     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
275     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
276     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
277     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
278     flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
279     * @param x x position, as an int
280     * @param y y position, as an int
281     * @param z z position, as an int
282     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
283     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z point with the given state s
284     */
285    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int z, int s) {
286        return (int)((0xDB4F0B9175AE2165L * x + 0xBBE0563303A4615FL * y + -0xA0F2EC75A1FE1575L * z + 0x89E182857D9ED689L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 59);
287    }
288
289    /**
290     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, and w into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious numbers,
291     * then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash, especially for
292     * ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by Pelle Evensen's
293     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary hash used here has
294     * been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected specifically to target
295     * flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
296     * @param x x position, as an int
297     * @param y y position, as an int
298     * @param z z position, as an int
299     * @param w w position, as an int
300     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
301     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w point with the given state s
302     */
303    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int z, int w, int s) {
304        return (int)((0xE19B01AA9D42C633L * x + 0xC6D1D6C8ED0C9631L * y + -0xAF36D01EF7518DBBL * z +
305                0x9A69443F36F710E7L * w + -0x881403B9339BD42DL * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 59);
306    }
307
308    /**
309     * A 5-bit point hash that smashes x, y, z, w, u, and v into s using XOR and multiplications by harmonious
310     * numbers, then runs a simple unary hash on s and returns it. Has better performance than HastyPointHash,
311     * especially for ints, and has slightly fewer collisions in a hash table of points. GWT-optimized. Inspired by
312     * Pelle Evensen's rrxmrrxmsx_0 unary hash, though this doesn't use its code or its full algorithm. The unary
313     * hash used here has been stripped down heavily, both for speed and because unless points are selected
314     * specifically to target flaws in the hash, it doesn't need the intense resistance to bad inputs that
315     * rrxmrrxmsx_0 has.
316     * @param x x position, as an int
317     * @param y y position, as an int
318     * @param z z position, as an int
319     * @param w w position, as an int
320     * @param u u position, as an int
321     * @param v v position, as an int
322     * @param s any int, a seed to be able to produce many hashes for a given point
323     * @return 5-bit hash of the x,y,z,w,u,v point with the given state s
324     */
325    public static int hash32(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int s) {
326        return (int)((0xE95E1DD17D35800DL * x + 0xD4BC74E13F3C782FL * y + -0xC1EDBC5B5C68AC25L * z +
327                0xB0C8AC50F0EDEF5DL * w + -0xA127A31C56D1CDB5L * u + 0x92E852C80D153DB3L * v -
328                0x85EB75C3024385C3L * s ^ 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L >>> 59);
329    }
